newsitem.title: HUNGARY: How big is Hungary's car market? GM asks.
newsitem.headline: How big is Hungary's car market? GM asks.

text.p: Opel Southeast Europe Ltd (OSE) said on Monday it questioned the accuracy of data on new car sales reported by automakers and importers in Hungary.

OSE, a unit of General Motors Corp's German automaker Adam Opel AG, said reports of sales totals for first-quarter this year were 35 percent above the number of new cars registrations reported by the Hungarian Ministry of Interior.
"We are extremely concerned about the differences (reported) in the market size -- the problem is big," Christopher Lacey, OSE's commercial director for souteast Europe, said at a news conference.
Automakers and importers reported selling 14,387 units, while the ministry reported 10,616 registrations, Lacey said.
The company with the biggest gap reported sales of 1,349 units, while the ministry reported 574 registrations, Lacey said.
Lacey did not identify this company, but the only one reporting this number of car sales was Ford Motor Co.
Ford said it had no comment but was reviewing the data.
The company reporting the largest sales volume of 3,123 units only had 1,962 units registered by the ministry, Lacey said.
These sales correspond to the volumes reported by Suzuki Motor Corp, which makes Swift hatchbacks and sedans in Hungary.
Opel, which has been the year-end market leader in Hungary since 1992, has been in dispute over sales data in the past with Suzuki, which has been second to Opel in sales since 1993.
Opel also owns roughly five percent of Suzuki, and the two companies have been negotiating jointly to design and build a mini car for Europe with production possibly in Hungary, Poland and Spain.
Suzuki's reported sales are ahead of Opel's reported sales of 2,166 units, but Opel's registrations of 1,999 units are the highest in the market, Lacey said without naming Suzuki.
"The registrations data change the market positions of the number one and the number two companies," Lacey said.

"We're not complaining, we're not criticising, we're big boys... but we are calling for realism," he added. "If we don't have realistic facts, people cannot make realistic decisions about the market."

Lacey said Opel was investigating the eight percent discrepancy in its own sales and registrations, adding that a possible explanation is that Opel has been including some of its commercial vehicle sales into its cars sales.
All major automakers and importers, except Suzuki, report their sales to the Hungarian Vehicle Importers Association, which consolidates the data for public release.
The association was not immediately available for comment.
